comments.commentBody: Teachers teachers can't take the time to read?  The rest of us do or hire someone to advise them of the real world.  Try the spy,index ,pay in to average your cost. It's call a bet in stocks s&p 500 will do better then a bond.
I would never check out of this life without a fight. Please keep fighting to live.
I encourage you to publish it I personally would love to read the story.
I noticed that the author bio included the following: `She lives in Chicago.' I hope that remains true for longer than Amy thinks.

To Martha Whitney, who wrote: "Nothing in this story says the fellow can support a family. I wouldn't look at him otherwise."

Wow. I don't even know what to say to such a heartless, mean-spirited comment.

Reading the comments, it occurred to me that more than a few readers didn't get it. I think I do. I feel about my husband the same way you feel about yours. Your tribute to him is beautiful; and whether he actually uses your last gift to him or not, he will always cherish the thought behind it.
Justin I am so sorry. I hope things are getting better. Somehow. Good luck.

The biggest issue with most retirement plans is the "wild-west" nature of the system. Most of the financial industry knows that obfuscation and opacity are their biggest allies. Transparency and clarity should be required in all financial relationships, yet much of Congress and the current administration believe that consumers are actually better served in the current system in which the odds are in the salespeople's favor.

Even without a global fiduciary standard, all advice and product providers should be required to disclose all fees, commissions, and surrender charges in a cover sheet (not buried in reams of disclosure documents).

In addition, annuity products should be banned from qualified retirement plans. They are tax-advantaged vehicles sold within tax-advantaged plans. So, while you pay extra in mortality expenses to gain that statutory tax-deferral, you can't have double tax deferral. Plus, the commissions and fees can be onerous.

Maybe a better system would involve a school district hiring a couple of fee-only advisors (with very low fees pre-negotiated) who offer only no-load, low fee funds along with an honest investing education that actually takes into account a client's tolerance and need for risk.
Why did Willy Sutton rob banks?  Retirement funds are where the money is today.  Too high fees and non-fiduciaries are paid first out of too modest returns.

Re spousal social security: at least in California you can collect spousal social security only if your benefit from Social Security will be higher than your teacher's pension. For career teachers, their teacher's pension pays more therefore they lose the spousal benefit of social security. Teachers should fact check this before retiring and monitor any rule changes thereafter. Congress has changed Social Security regs in off election years such as raising minimum age to receive full benefits.

Westsider, that's an interesting theory, that all this stuff about Russia is just a way to cook up more business for the military industrial complex. But is that why Europeans are also concerned about Russia's cyberattacks and funding of the far right?

Truth is, I think we have more than one big problem on our hands. And a president who is too self-involved to be any help at all.

Unions and politics are the alliance that keep the status quo in these deals. Look at PA, home of Vanguard. Local school districts will not offer Vanguard (of Fidelity) as they will not pay to play. Unions will not negotiate to expand the choices beyond the poor options available with huge fees. The advisory firms make contributions to the teacher's union. The great circle of life continues. Thanks to the Times for this series...good work.
Amy is an "Amazing Love" -  truly she is Love-in Action.

Half of workers in America don't have access to a 401k, so no chance to save for retirement.

Of the ones who have access half don't contribute at all, leaving the company match on the table.

Of the ones who do contribute, they contribute up to the match. On the median income of $50,000 a 3% match is $1,500 $1,500 in contributions that is only $3,000 in contribution annually. Try to retire on that, as many workers never raise their contributions.

Many workers use their 401k as a piggy bank, always borrowing, paying extra taxes and fees and never letting the money compound.

And on top of all that, the fees, the high fees. "Oh the fund charges only 1.5%". What exactly does that cost? On $10,000 that is $150 dollars, fees that you can see. Behind the scenes depending on the investments, the fees run as high as 4% because of all the trading or $400.

Now on an index fund that $10,000 would only charge .003%, or a grand total of $30. Quite a difference. And here is where the racket of "choices" come in . Except those "choices" never include low fee funds.

And that is how billions of dollars in fees are stolen from the American workers who will have nothing to show for a lifetime of work.

Spiegel.de just issued an article about Your letter. I am deeply impressed of Your power to love. Although I am very sorry that You must leave, but I think, Your life must have been one of the greatest. All my sympathy for You, Your husband and Your children.

2 1/2 months off every summer that are without pay, I might add. And that is if one is fortunate enough to not need to teach summer school or get a temporary position to supplement the $25,000 a year starting salary (e.g. Arizona) or even $37,000 (e.g. California) offered by your district.

If you think you are reassuring her with your exhortations of miracles, reassess, please. Perhaps her miracle is the love she gave and received. Who are we to judge what is "enough" for any other person?
Just pay the teachers more and let them invest the money themselves. Having some sort of "plan" is just an opportunity for someone else to line their pockets.
I'm crying
Ah, my dear, more good days.

Your post is as wonderful as Ms Rosenthal 's essay, filled with real love. Bless you Donna and your husband. And as I said before too, miracles do happen. May Ms Rosenthal beats this illness and live a long life with her loving family.
He will love again because he was loved.

Wow! If you needed to know what love sounds looks like, reading this gives you a clear picture. If you need to know what love sounds like, read this out loud. For me, the courage this took is over the top and whether it works or not I have nothing but respect for author and subject. I am not one for prayer but I am praying for the entire family as I write this and I hope that the universe is listening. Wow!

I can only imagine the "dating profile" your j would write for you.  I can tell from his bio that you are  the beautiful lid to his perfect pot.   How moving and touching your constant and undying love for him is.  You are the definition of true love.

Thank you for sharing this very personal and touching tribute to your husband and marriage.  Moreover, thank you for reminding me to look at every day with my wife as a gift that should be cherished, lived fully, and never taken for granted.  I'm going to run out and buy my wife some flowers right now.  From the article, I surmise you are 52 or so, but whether I face your plight at 52 or 92, I know saying goodbye to my love will be the most heartbreaking experience I will ever have.  God bless you and your family.
True love, of course, includes much reciprocity.  I am sure you discovered your husband is a wonderful human being because you, too, are a wonderful human being.
